title: Communicating About Intimacy
description: Explore how you talk about your intimate life together.

questions.text: Talking about our intimate life feels...
choices: Natural—I'm comfortable discussing it
Important but a bit vulnerable
Awkward—I'd rather show than tell
Easier at some times than others

therapeutic.rationale: Comfort discussing intimacy varies widely. Natural-talkers communicate easily; vulnerable-but-willing types push through discomfort; show-don't-tellers prefer action; variable types have context-dependent comfort. Mismatched comfort creates communication gaps.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: The natural-talker may push conversations the uncomfortable partner dreads; the show-don't-teller may leave the talker feeling disconnected. Go at the pace of the less comfortable person.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared comfort level makes intimate communication flow more easily.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How comfortable are you talking about your intimate life? What makes it easier or harder?

questions.text: When I want something different in our intimate life, I tend to...
choices: Bring it up directly
Hint or suggest subtly
Show them through actions
Wait and hope they notice

therapeutic.rationale: How we communicate desires shapes whether they're met. Direct-askers get clarity; hint-droppers hope for pickup; action-showers demonstrate; waiters often stay unsatisfied. Clearer communication leads to better outcomes.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different styles may mean missed messages. The direct-asker may overwhelm the subtle partner; the hint-dropper's messages may be missed entirely. Find a communication style that works for both.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared communication style makes understanding each other easier. You'll naturally send and receive messages similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you typically communicate what you want intimately? Does your partner know what you want?

questions.text: If my partner told me something they'd like to try, I'd want to...
choices: Listen openly without judgment
Understand why it appeals to them
Share my honest reaction respectfully
All of these—open dialogue matters

therapeutic.rationale: How we receive intimate requests affects whether partners feel safe sharing. Open-listeners create safety; understanders seek connection; honest-sharers maintain boundaries; all-of-these types value complete dialogue. Judgment shuts down communication.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these responses are healthy. The key is creating safety for requests while maintaining your own boundaries.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared response values create mutual safety for intimate communication.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when your partner shares an intimate request? Do you create safety for their vulnerability?

questions.text: The conversation I'd most want us to have about our intimate life is...
choices: What we each enjoy and want more of
How to keep things fresh and connected
How to navigate when we're not in sync
How to feel even safer with each other

therapeutic.rationale: Desired conversations reveal needs. Enjoyment-focusers want pleasure optimization; freshness-seekers want novelty; sync-navigators want conflict resolution; safety-builders want deeper trust. All are important conversations.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different conversation priorities are fine—you can have all of them. Start with whatever feels most pressing.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared conversation priority focuses your intimate communication. You're both wanting to address the same thing.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What conversation about intimacy would help your relationship most right now?

questions.text: Giving feedback about intimate experiences is something I...
choices: Do naturally—I want us both to enjoy
Find difficult but know it's important
Prefer to do in the moment, gently
Would rather do afterward, not during

therapeutic.rationale: Feedback style affects improvement. Natural-feedbackers communicate easily; difficult-but-trying types push through; in-the-moment types redirect live; afterward-talkers process later. All can work if feedback actually happens.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different feedback styles need coordination. The in-the-moment partner may surprise the afterward-talker; the natural-feedbacker may overwhelm the finds-it-difficult partner. Agree on your approach.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared feedback style makes giving and receiving input smoother. You'll naturally communicate about experiences similarly.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you feel about giving feedback about intimate experiences? What would make it easier?
